question: Is the assembly of invadopodia triggered by focal generation of phosphatidylinositol 3,4-bisphosphate and activation of the nonreceptor tyrosine kinase Src? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: The expression of various phosphoinositide-binding domains revealed that the podosomes in Src-transformed NIH3T3 (NIH-src) cells are enriched with PtdIns(3,4)P2, suggesting an important role of this phosphoinositide in podosome formation.
content.source_2: In invasive MDA-MB-231 cells, live-cell TIRF imaging with a fluorescent PI(3,4)P2 biosensor detected no focal PI(3,4)P2 signal preceding invadopodia nucleation; furthermore, acute Src inhibition with PP2 did not reduce initiation events, indicating assembly proceeds independently of local PI(3,4)P2 generation and Src activation.
content.source_3: Live-cell imaging analysis revealed that Src-expression stimulated podosome formation at focal adhesions of NIH3T3 cells after PtdIns(3,4)P2 accumulation.
content.source_4: Quantitative lipidomics coupled with biosensor imaging showed that PtdIns(3,4,5)P3, not PtdIns(3,4)P2, was enriched at nascent invadopodia, and CRISPR/Cas9-mediated Src knockout increased the number of matrix-degrading puncta, arguing against a requirement for Src activity in assembly.
